definition.value: A monitoring behaviour in which a carer gathers information about the activities of some child in their care.
A population behaviour that is aimed at achieving a goal shared by members of that population.
An individual human behaviour that has the goal to reduce harm or discomfort.
An antisocial behaviour that is illegal in a jurisdiction.
A regulatory behaviour in which cues that prompt a behaviour pattern are added, altered or removed.
An individual human behaviour within a residential facility.
An individual human behaviour that is emotionally driven.
A behavioural attribute in which the behaviour is caused by an emotion process.
An expressive behaviour that conveys some emotion.
An environmental system management behaviour that contributes to sustaining the ecosystem.
A behavioural frequency about the number of times a person has enacted a behaviour per unit of time.
An individual human behaviour that has a behavioural goal.
An individual human behaviour that has an outcome to prevent harm.
A behavioural consequence in which harm is prevented.
A health-related behaviour that improves the person’s health.
This class is for behaviour that promote positive health as well as protect against threats to health.
A behavioural attribute that is the extent to which one’s behaviour is believed to be consistent with one’s core, positive self-identity.
A behavioural consequence that involves an outcome relating to the environment system.

label.value: knowledge acquisition about reducing harmful behaviours

definition.value: A knowledge development behaviour where the knowledge is about how to reduce or avoid a harmful behaviour.
A knowledge development behaviour that involves gathering information over a period of time.
This is often used in relation to regulatory behaviour, either oneself or others. 'Monitoring behaviour' has part 'regulatory behaviour'
Nurture behaviour that is provided to a young person by someone in a parent role.

label.value: past occurrence of a target behaviour

definition.value: An individual human behaviour that is the target of an intervention and has been previously enacted.
This is a relational class (relates one behaviour to another).
A behavioural consequence that is positively evaluated by an individual or a population.
An economic behaviour in which the person gives money in exchange for a service or ownership of a product.
A process in which physical or mental uneasiness or distress is reduced.
A process in which damage or injury is reduced.
An individual human behaviour that is reflectively driven.
A behavioural attribute in which the behaviour is caused by a reflective mental process.
An individual human behaviour that involves monitoring and acting upon some parts of the person or their environment.
Environment here includes the social and physical environment and includes behaviours involved in monitoring of others or self, action planning, and goal setting.
A behavioural attribute that is the time, effort, financial cost, or aversiveness of enacting a behaviour.
A social influence behaviour in which the person provides a positive stimulus contingent on another person’s behaviour.
An economic behaviour in which the person provides a service or ownership of a product in exchange for money.
An individual human behaviour that occurs after the behaviour has been subject to extinction in operant learning.
A process attribute that is the complexity of thought or behaviour required to achieve a goal.
A goal-directed behaviour that has a goal to reduce threat.
Reducing a threat involves trying to reduce the harm of something that may occur in the future.
An experience-related behaviour that involves taking action to engage with some stimulus that is judged to be rewarding by the person.
A <person> that influences a recipient by being perceived to be similar or admired.
This class lies at the intersection between a person and their environment and is defined from the perspective of the person.

label.value: accepting responsibility for changing one’s behaviour

definition.value: An <emotional-relevance appraisal process> in which the person comes to feel that they have a responsibility to change their behaviour.
<Planning> that has as a part some goal that is specified in terms of some behaviour and a time or place where the behaviour is to be enacted.
An <emotional-relevance appraisal process> that results in an appraisal of the consequence of some behaviour.
An <individual human behaviour> in which a person substitutes a more desired behaviour for a less desired behaviour.
A <group belief> in which members of a group falsely believe that their own beliefs and behaviours are unusual.
An <imagination capability> in which what is imagined are scenarios that could happen in the future.
Scenarios include possible, outcomes of behaviours, goals and actions to achieve them.
A <cognitive bias process> that overweights an outcome that is judged to be certain compared with ones that are judged to be less than certain.
A <mental disposition> that is realised as a cognitive bias process.
A <cognitive process> that leads to systematic error in judgement or belief.
A <cognitive process> in which a person substitutes a more desired thought process for a less desired thought process.

label.value: comparison of current behaviour with a standard

definition.value: <Comparison of current situation with a standard> where the focus is on current behaviour.

label.value: decisional balance process about changing behaviour

definition.value: <Decision-making> in which the person compares the pros and cons of changing a behaviour pattern.
A <belief> that a proposition is not true, not important or not relevant.
A <denial belief> that holds that the person does not have a specific bodily or psychological need in a given scenario.
This can include any type of need.
